We have also included an additional section on the reduction in the rate of IHT for gifts of 10% or more of the net estate to charity.

section1.title: Introduction to inheritance tax
section1.para:
Inheritance tax (IHT) is primarily a charge on an individual's
estate
on death. However, it can also arise on certain lifetime gifts, for example:

listitem.para: Gifts to certain trusts (seeInheritance tax and trusts: relevant property trusts).
Gifts to companies (seeGifts to companies).
Gifts involving close companies (see Gifts made by close companies andAlteration of share capital).

section1.para:
Ongoing IHT charges can also arise on trust property under the
relevant property regime
(seeInheritance tax and trusts: relevant property regime)

In addition, IHT may be payable on outright gifts made within seven years of an individual's death. This is mainly to catch those who try to avoid an IHT charge by giving away their estate shortly before they die. These are called
potentially exempt transfers
(PETs) (seePotentially exempt transfers).

The word "gift" is not used in the IHT legislation, although it is used in this note for ease. The legislation actually uses defined terms such as "disposition", "transfer of value" and "chargeable transfer", which cover a wide range of circumstances not always immediately recognised as being "gifts". The purpose is to cover lifetime transactions that result in a loss to the donor's estate (and an increase in the donee's estate), unless the transaction is for genuine commercial reasons and there is no gratuitous intent.

The legislation does not only cover gifts of cash or specific assets. It also covers, for example, sales of assets (for less than their full market value) to certain family members, fixed-term interest free loans and the rent-free use of property. There are also specific types of "excluded property" which fall outside the scope of the IHT legislation.

Every individual has a nil rate band in which IHT is charged at 0% (seeThe nil rate band). In addition to this, there are allowances, exemptions and reliefs which reduce the amount of IHT payable, if certain conditions are met.

The IHT legislation is contained in the Inheritance Tax Act 1984 (IHTA 1984).
HM Revenue & Customs
(HMRC) have published detailed guidance on this topic, which is contained in HMRC: Inheritance Tax Manual (IHT manual).

section2.title: Future review?
section2.para: On 3 March 2011, the Office of Tax Simplification (OTS) published a final report on its tax reliefs review, which was commissioned by the Coalition government in November 2010. In its report, the OTS recommended that IHT reliefs be reviewed in the context of a separate review of IHT as a whole and that any review of IHT must include a review of the taxation of trusts (seeLegal update, Final report on tax reliefs review: private client exemptions and reliefs: Reliefs to be reviewed separately). For the latest information on the OTS review of tax reliefs and the government's response to the review, seePrivate client tax legislation tracker 2011-12: Office of Tax Simplification reviews.

HMRC published a The government announced, in its Budget on 21 March 2012, that it will p ublish a consultation document in July 2012 on its plans to simplify the way IHT is calculated for ten yearly charges and exit charges inrelevant property trusts. The month set for publication is now known to be July 2012. It will publish a further consultation on these reforms in the spring of 2013. To follow the outcome of the consultation, seePrivate client legislation tracker 2012-13: IHT: simplifying calculations for relevant property trusts. For more information on how relevant property trusts are currently taxed, see Relevant property trusts.

section1.title: Territorial scope of inheritance tax
section1.para:
The extent to which an individual is charged to IHT depends on their
domicile
status:

listitem.para: An individual who is domiciled in the UK is subject to IHT on their worldwide estate.
An individual who is not domiciled in the UK is subject to IHT only on their UK estate.

section1.para: "Domicile" is a complex concept which is based on a long line of cases in the field of international law. It has been incorporated into the IHT legislation as a means of reducing exposure to IHT for those who have only a temporary link with the UK.

In this context, domicile has a specific legal meaning, beyond the simple dictionary definition of "place of residence". An individual can be resident in the UK for many years and yet be domiciled elsewhere. In certain (more unusual) circumstances, an individual can also be domiciled in the UK without having set foot here. For further information on domicile, see Practice note, Domicile.

In addition, Parliament decided that certain individuals should be subject to IHT on their worldwide estate, even though they are not domiciled in the UK under the general law. The rationale for this is that they have lived in the UK for a long time and should therefore contribute more tax. The following individuals are "deemed domiciled" in the UK for IHT purposes:

listitem.para: Individuals who have lived in the UK for at least 17 out of the previous 20 tax years. These individuals will be "deemed domiciled" in the UK from the start of their 17th tax year of residence.
UK domiciled individuals who leave the UK and acquire a new domicile abroad. These individuals will be "deemed domiciled" for three years following the date they acquired their new domicile.

section1.para: (Section 267 , IHTA 1984.)
Examples of how these rules work can be found inPractice note, Domicile: Deemed domicile.

section1.title: The charge to tax
section1.para: Broadly, IHT is charged as follows:

listitem.para: On death, in relation to a deceased person's estate. This includes:
gifts made in the seven years prior to death (see Potentially exempt transfers); and
gifts with reservation of benefit.
On chargeable lifetime gifts. For example:
Gifts torelevant property trusts.
Gifts to companies.
Gifts by close companies.
An alteration of share capital by close companies.
On trust property under the relevant property regime (seeInheritance tax and trusts: relevant property trusts).

section1.title: The rate of tax
section1.para: IHT is charged at the following rates:

listitem.para: On the nil rate band amount, the rate of tax is 0% (that is, there is no IHT to pay).
On the balance, the rate of tax is:
20% for chargeable lifetime gifts (seeThe charge to tax); and
40% on estates on death (or 36% where 10% or more of the net estate is given to charity, see10% reduction in rate of inheritance tax for gifts to charity).

section1.para: (Section 7 , IHTA 1984.)
Relevant property trusts have their own charging regime (see Inheritance tax and trusts: relevant property trusts).
For more information on IHT rates and allowances, seePractice note, Tax data for individuals and trustees.

Paragraph 207 and Schedule 32 of the Finance Bill 2012 provide for the application of a reduced rate of IHT to the estates of deceased individuals who leave 10% or more of their net estate to charity. For further information on this measure, seePractice note, Inheritance tax: leaving 10% of an estate to charity. To follow the progress of the measure towards implementation, seePrivate client tax legislation tracker 2011-12: IHT: reduced rate for charitable testators.

section1.title: The nil rate band
section1.para: The nil rate band is so called, because it is the amount which is chargeable to IHT at 0%. Each individual currently has a maximum nil rate band amount of £325,000 . It was announced in the 2009 Budget that the nil rate band amount would be frozen at £325,000 until 5 February 2015. , which is frozen until 5 April 2015 (seeJune 2010 Budget: key private client tax announcements: IHT nil rate band to remain frozen at £325,000 until 5 April 2015) . The Secretary of State for Health, Jeremy Hunt, announced on 11 February 2013 that the nil rate band would be frozen at this level for a further three years from 2015-16 to meet part of the costs of changes to the funding of social care.
This is the maximum amount, because the nil rate band can be used up in lifetime by:

listitem.para: Chargeable lifetime gifts.
PETs made within the seven years before death.

section1.para:
In the 2011 Budget, the government announced that from 2015-16, the
consumer prices index
(CPI) would be used as the "default indexation assumption" for the nil rate band, instead of the
retail prices index
(RPI). Draft legislation was published on 6 December 2011 for inclusion in the Finance Bill 2012. The draft legislation provides for automatic indexation of the nil rate band each year, using the CPI over the year to the previous September, although this may be overridden for a tax year if Parliament sets a different figure. To follow the progress of this measure towards implementation, seePrivate client tax legislation tracker 2011-12: IHT: CPI indexation of nil rate band.
For further information about the nil rate band, seePractice note, Inheritance tax transferable nil rate band: overview.
For historic nil rate band amounts, seeHMRC: Inheritance Tax thresholds.
For more information on IHT rates and allowances, seePractice note, Tax data for individuals and trustees.

section2.title: Surviving spouse or civil partner can inherit unused portion of nil rate band
section2.para:
As a result of a change introduced by theFinance Act 2008, a surviving spouse or
civil partner
(who dies on or after 9 October 2007) can now effectively "inherit" the unused percentage of their deceased spouse or partner's nil rate band.

For example, Jermaine dies in September 2007 and, on death, has assets of £500,000. His nil rate band of £300,000 is fully intact. He leaves a £75,000 legacy to his daughter Dot, and the remainder of his estate to his wife Marnie.

listitem.para: No IHT is payable on the assets passing to Marnie, because of the spouse exemption (seeGifts to a spouse or civil partner).
No IHT is payable on the legacy to Dot because it falls within Jermaine's nil rate band.
Jermaine has essentially "wasted" 75% of his nil rate band.

section2.para: On Marnie's death in September 2008, she has assets of £600,000 in her estate. Her nil rate band of £312,000 is fully intact. She leaves everything to Dot.

listitem.para: If Marnie had died before 9 October 2007, the IHT payable on her estate would have been £115,200 (£600,000 - £312,000 x 40%).

Since she died after that date, the Finance Act 2008 will apply. Because Jermaine did not use 75% of his nil rate band, Marnie's executors can claim an additional 75% of the nil rate band amount in force at the date of her death. Her "uplifted" nil rate band is therefore £546,000 (£312,000 + £234,000). The IHT payable on her death is therefore £21,600 (£600,000 - £546,000 x 40%).

section1.title: Inheritance tax and trusts
section1.para: For IHT purposes, trusts broadly fall into two categories, which are discussed further below:

listitem.para: Relevant property trusts.
Trusts with a qualifying interest in possession.

section1.para: There are other categories of trust that don't fall into these categories:

listitem.para:
Bare trusts
(the assets are treated as belonging to the beneficiary for tax purposes so no special trust rules apply).
Certain types of trust have preferential treatment for IHT purposes:

trusts for bereaved minors
;

certain
accumulation and maintenance trusts
; and

18 to 25 trusts
.
For more information on the IHT treatment of these types of trust, seePractice note, Taxation of UK trusts: overview: How IHT applies to trusts.

section2.title: Relevant property trusts
section2.para:
Relevant property trusts
have their own IHT regime (most of the legislative provisions are found inChapter III , Part III, IHTA 1984). Under this regime, an IHT charge can arise:

listitem.para: When assets are given to the trust.
On every ten-year anniversary of the creation of the trust.
When capital is distributed to beneficiaries.

section2.para: The gift of assets to a relevant property trust is a chargeable lifetime transfer, triggering an immediate 20% charge to IHT. In addition, if the settlor fails to survive seven years from the date he gives assets to the trust, further IHT may be due.

Broadly, the rate of tax is up to 6% on each ten-year anniversary (charged on the value of the trust fund) and when capital is distributed from the trust (charged on the value of the distribution). For more information, see Practice notes, Inheritance tax: relevant property trusts: key concepts
andInheritance tax: relevant property trusts: calculating the charge to tax.Practice note, Taxation of UK trusts: overview: How IHT applies to trusts: relevant property trusts.

The disclosure of tax avoidance schemes (DOTAS) regime includes IHT on lifetime transfers by individuals to relevant property trusts with effect from 6 April 2011. For further information, seePractice note, Taxation of UK trusts: overview: How IHT applies to trusts: Relevant property trusts: Anti-avoidance measures.

section2.title: Trusts with a qualifying interest in possession
section2.para:
Trusts with a
qualifying interest in possession
are taxed as though the beneficiary with the interest in possession (called the
life tenant
) owns the trust assets ( Chapter II , Part III, IHTA 1984 ). The trust is therefore taxed as though it forms part of the life tenant's estate. Gifts to certain types of qualifying interest in possession trusts are PETs.
For more information, seePractice note, Taxation of UK trusts: overview: How IHT applies to trusts: qualifying IIP trusts.

section1.title: Inheritance tax and companies
section1.para: Although IHT relates to individuals, not companies, there are three areas where gifts to or from companies can result in an IHT charge:

listitem.para: Gifts to companies.
Gifts made by close companies.
An alteration of share capital by close companies.

section2.title: Gifts to companies
section2.para: A gift to a company constitutes a chargeable lifetime transfer because it does not constitute a PET (section 7 , IHTA 1984). This means that:

listitem.para: There is a lifetime charge to IHT at 20% on the value of the gift (strictly, the loss to the donor's estate). This is subject to any available exemptions and reliefs and also to the donor's available nil rate band.

If the donor fails to survive for seven years from the date of the gift, the gift will become chargeable to IHT at 40%. Again, this is subject to any available exemptions and reliefs and with credit given for any IHT paid during lifetime. As with PETs, taper relief will be due if the donor survives for at least three years from the date of the gift (seeAmount of tax charged depends on how long the donor survives).

section2.para: Unlike gifts torelevant property trusts, however, there are no ongoing IHT charges.

section2.title: Gifts made by close companies
section2.para: Because IHT is payable by individuals and not companies, an anti-avoidance measure was introduced to stop individuals trying to avoid IHT by making gifts through private family companies.

Where a gift is made by a
close company
, it is treated as having been made by the participators (Section 94 , IHTA 1984). However, because it is only a "deemed" gift by the participators, it is not a PET and so there may be an immediate charge to IHT. Further, not all of the exemptions are available.
The following exemptionsareavailable:

listitem.para: Annual exemption (section 19(5) , IHTA 1984).
Spouse or civil partner exemption (section 18 , IHTA 1984).
Charities exemption (section 23 , IHTA 1984).
Political parties exemption (section 24 , IHTA 1984).
Gifts of land to housing associations (section 24A , IHTA 1984).
Gifts for national purposes (section 25 , IHTA 1984).

section2.para: The following exemptions are not available:

listitem.para: The small gifts exemption (section 20 , IHTA 1984).
Normal gifts out of income (section 21 , IHTA 1984).
Gifts in consideration of marriage (section 22 , IHTA 1984).

section2.para: When a gift is made by a close company, any IHT is payable primarily by the company. However if the company does not pay, HMRC can go after the participators (except for those whose interest in the company is 5% or less) or the donee of the gift.
For more information, seeIHT manual: Lifetime transfers: transfer of value by a close company.

section2.title: Alteration of share capital
section2.para: The participators of a close company are deemed to make a chargeable lifetime gift where:

listitem.para: There is an alteration in, or extinguishment of, the company's unquoted shares or loan capital.

There is an alteration in, or extinguishment of, rights attaching to any shares in, or
debentures
of, that company which are unquoted.
Either of the above result in a reduction in the value of the participator's estate.

section2.para: (Section 100 , IHTA 1984.)
However, usual IHT principles apply, so there is no gift where the alteration is done for genuine commercial purposes and there is no gratuitous intent.
As with gifts made by close companies, these are not PETs. The comments made above about exemptions therefore apply equally here.
For more information, seeIHT manual: Lifetime transfers: alteration in the share capital of a close company.

section1.title: Excluded property
section1.para: Certain types of property are excluded from IHT. In some cases the domicile status of the owner is not relevant and in other cases only non-UK domiciled individuals can benefit from the exemption.

section2.title: All individuals, regardless of domicile status
section2.para: For all individuals (regardless of domicile), the following are excluded:

listitem.para: it was not purchased; and
neither the settlor (nor his spouse or civil partner) owns (or has ever owned) the reversionary interest.
(Section 48 , IHTA 1984.)

Decorations awarded for bravery (not purchased) (previously Extra Statutory Concession F19, now section 6(1B) of IHTA 1984). (See Legal update, Order made enacting extra-statutory concessions
andLegal update, HMRC updates guidance on settlor-trustee tax adjustments and awards for gallantry.)

An interest in an "excluded property" trust (unless it is an
interest in possession
purchased by a UK domiciled individual). Broadly, an excluded property trust is:
a trust created by a settlor who was neither domiciled nor deemed domiciled in the UK when he gave assets to it; and
which holds only non-UK assets.

For information on the interaction between excluded property trusts and the gifts with reservation of benefit rules, seeLegal update, HMRC confirms that excluded property trumps reservation of benefit for non-dom trusts.

section2.title: Individuals not domiciled in the UK
section2.para: For individuals who are not domiciled in the UK under general law (whether or not they are "deemed" domiciled for IHT purposes), exempt UK government securities are also excluded property.

section2.title: Individuals domiciled in the Channel Islands or Isle of Man
section2.para: For individuals domiciled in the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man (whether or not they are "deemed" domiciled for IHT purposes), the following additional assets are excluded:

listitem.para:
War savings certificates
.
Premium bonds.

National Savings and Investment
bank deposits.

section2.title: Individuals neither domiciled nor deemed domiciled in the UK
section2.para: For individuals who are neither domiciled nor deemed domiciled in the UK, the following additional assets are excluded:

listitem.para: Any non-UK property.

Holdings in
authorised unit trusts
and shares in
open ended investment companies
(OEICs).

section2.para: (Section 6 , IHTA 1984.)
For more information, seeIHT manual: Property excluded from Inheritance Tax.

section1.title: Exemptions available for both lifetime gifts and on death
section1.para: Gifts to certain favoured individuals or bodies are exempt from IHT (and do not use up the nil rate band). They are as follows:

listitem.para: Gifts to aspouse or civil partner.
Gifts tocharities.
Gifts topolitical parties.
Gifts ofland to housing associations.
Gifts fornational purposes.
Gifts toheritage maintenance funds.
Transfers to employee trusts.

section2.title: Gifts to a spouse or civil partner
section2.para: IHT is not payable on any gift made between spouses or civil partners during lifetime or on death, provided that:

listitem.para: Both parties are domiciled in the UK for IHT purposes (that is, they are either domiciled or deemed domiciled in the UK); or
Both parties are domiciled outside the UK for IHT purposes (that is, they are neither domiciled, nor deemed domiciled in the UK).

section2.para: (Section 18 , IHTA 1984.)

If one spouse or civil partner is domiciled in the UK for IHT purposes and the other is not, there is an upper limit to the spouse exemption in relation to gifts made to the non-UK domiciled spouse. The limit is £55,000 overall, whether the gifts are made in lifetime or on death. This limit also applies when calculating the transferable nil rate band that can be claimed by the personal representatives of a non-UK domiciled spouse who is predeceased by a UK domiciled spouse.
The spouse exemption is available in full in relation to gifts made to the UK domiciled spouse.

A useful way to remember this is to consider the rationale. When assets pass from a UK domiciled spouse to a non-UK domiciled spouse, they are potentially leaving the IHT "net" forever (because the non-UK domiciled spouse may not be subject to IHT on his or her death). By limiting the spouse exemption in these circumstances, the lion's share of IHT is secured on the first spouse's death.

The government announced in its 2012 Budget on 21 March 2012 that it would publish a consultation document, with draft legislation, on its plans to increase the amount that a UK domiciled spouse or civil partner can give to his non-domiciled spouse or civil partner free from IHT. The legislation will form part of Finance Bill 2013. The consultation will propose an increase in the spouse exemption from £55,000 to £325,000 that will then track any future increases in the nil rate band. There will also be an option for the non-domiciled spouse to elect to be treated as deemed domiciled so that they can benefit from the unlimited spouse exemption that gifts to UK-domiciled spouses and civil partners currently enjoy. It is now known that the consultation will be published in May 2012.

The government published draft legislation on 11 December 2012 to increase the amount that a UK domiciled individual can transfer to his non-UK domiciled spouse or civil partner free from IHT. The measure will raise the £55,000 limit to the level of the prevailing IHT nil rate band. Non-UK domiciled individuals who have a UK domiciled spouse or civil partner will be able to elect to be treated as UK domiciled for IHT purposes. The legislation will have effect for transfers made on or after 6 April 2013.
For more information on the spouse exemption generally, seeIHT Manual: Spouse or civil partner exemption.

section2.title: Gifts to charities
section2.para: Outright gifts to UK, EU and Norwegian and Icelandic charities (or to charitable trusts from which only these charities may benefit) are exempt from IHT ( paragraph 1, Schedule 6, Finance Act 2010). For more information on the definition of charity for tax purposes seePractice note, What is a charity: definition of charity for tax legislation.
For more information on the charity exemption for IHT, seeIHT Manual: Charity exemption.
For information on the reduced rate of IHT for estates of deceased individuals who leave 10% or more of their net estate to charity, seeThe rate of tax.

section2.title: Gifts to political parties
section2.para: Gifts to UK political parties are exempt, provided that the party is of sufficient stature. The requirements are that either of the following applied (as at the last general election):

listitem.para: At least two members of the party were elected to the House of Commons.
At least one member of the party was so elected and at least 150,000 votes were given to candidates who were members of that party.

section2.para: (Section 24 , IHTA 1984.)
For more information, seeIHT manual: Gifts to political parties.

section2.title: Gifts of land to housing associations
section2.para: Gifts of land to housing associations or to registered social landlords are exempt from IHT (section 24A , IHTA 1984).
For more information, seeIHT manual: Gifts to registered housing associations.

section2.title: Gifts for national purposes
section2.para: Gifts for national purposes are exempt from IHT. The IHT legislation contains a list of bodies and institutions that are covered by this exemption. For example:

listitem.para: The National Gallery or British Museum or another national institution which exists wholly or mainly for the purpose of preserving a collection of scientific, historic or artistic interest for the public benefit.
Any museum or art gallery in the UK which exists wholly or mainly for the purpose stated above.
Any library, the main function of which is to serve the needs of teaching and research at a university in the UK.

section2.para: (Section 25 and Schedule 3 , IHTA 1984.)
For more information, seeIHT manual: Gifts for National Purposes.

In the 2011 Budget, the government announced that it would consult on a proposal to introduce a tax reduction for taxpayers who give a work of art or historical object of national importance to the State. The consultation ran from 29 June 2011 to 21 September 2011. On 6 December 2011, the government published draft legislation for inclusion in the Finance Bill 2012. For further information on this measure and to follow its progress towards implementation, seePrivate client tax legislation tracker 2011-12: Tax reduction for gifts of art to the nation.

section2.title: Gifts to heritage maintenance funds
section2.para: Heritage maintenance funds are trusts that maintain historic buildings or land of scenic, scientific or historic interest. A gift to a heritage maintenance fund is exempt from IHT. The fund does not incur any ongoing IHT charges as long as it meets the following conditions:

listitem.para: The trustees must:
be approved by the Treasury;
contain at least one trustee from a requisite professional body; and
must be resident in the UK when HMRC give their direction as to whether the trust qualifies.
The fund must be used (for a minimum period of six years from the date it was given to the trust) for:
the maintenance, repair or preservation of the heritage property;
other charities that exist for such purposes;
making provision for public access to the heritage property; or
national purposes (seeGifts for national purposes).

section2.para: (Section 27 and Schedule 4 , IHTA 1984.)

HMRC determines whether the building or land is sufficiently important to merit the exemption (seePractice note, Inheritance tax: conditional exemption for heritage property: What constitutes heritage property?).

For more information, see IHT manual: Exemptions: maintenance funds (paragraph IHTM11250)
and HMRC: Capital Taxation and the National Heritage (September 2011)
(Chapter 8).

section2.title: Transfers to employee trusts
section2.para:
A transfer of shares by an individual to an
employee benefit trust
(EBT) is exempt provided that:

listitem.para: The shares are held:
on trust for the benefit of all or most of the employees or office holders of the company; or
under an approved profit sharing scheme or share incentive plan.

At the time of (or within one year of) the transfer, the trustees hold more than half of the
ordinary shares
in the company and have voting control on all questions affecting the company as a whole.
The trust cannot be used to benefit any shareholder who is entitled to:
5% or more of any class of shares in the company; or
5% or more of its assets on winding up.

section2.para: (Section 28 , IHTA 1984.)
For more information, seeIHT manual: Employee Benefit Trusts (from IHTM42900).
For information on the IHT issues that arise where an EBT is established by a close company, seeLegal update, HMRC publishes guidance on taxation of EBTs.
For information on EBTs generally, seePractice note, Trusts in commercial transactions: Employee benefit trusts.

section1.title: Exemptions available for lifetime gifts only
section1.para: Additional exemptions are also available for lifetime gifts, if none of the above exemptions apply. The most commonly used exemptions are as follows:

listitem.para: Normal expenditure out of income.
Small gifts to any one person.
Wedding and civil partnership gifts.
Annual exemption.

section1.para: Note that the "normal expenditure out of income" exemption is applied first and the "annual" exemption is applied last, after all the other exemptions.

section2.title: Normal expenditure out of income
section2.para: Lifetime gifts are exempt if they form part of the donor's normal expenditure out of (after tax) income, provided that the donor is left with sufficient income to maintain his usual standard of living (section 21 , IHTA 1984).
A regular pattern of giving is required, for example meeting annual school fees for a grandchild or paying the premiums on a life policy for another's benefit.

The first gift in a series can qualify, provided further gifts are intended. If the donor dies before making the second gift, there must be sufficient evidence that he intended to make a series of gifts.
For more information, seeIHT manual: Normal expenditure out of income.

section2.title: Small gifts to any one person
section2.para: Lifetime gifts of up to £250 to any one individual during a tax year are exempt (section 20 , IHTA 1984). The exemption is only available if the gift (or gifts) to that individual does not exceed £250 in total. It is not possible to carry forward any unused portion to the next tax year.
For example, an individual makes a number of gifts to the same individual during a tax year and the gifts total £300. The small gifts exemption does not apply to any part of the gift(s).
For more information, seeIHT manual: Specific lifetime exemptions: small gifts exemption.

section2.title: Wedding and civil partnership gifts
section2.para: Lifetime gifts on the occasion of a marriage or registration of a civil partnership are exempt up to certain limits (section 22 , IHTA 1984). The amount of the limit depends on the relationship of the donor to the couple, as follows:

listitem.para: Each parent can give £5,000.
Each grandparent (or remoter ancestor) can give £2,500.
Either of the couple can give to each other £2,500.
Any other person can give £1,000.

section2.para: The gifts can be made to either party of the marriage or civil partnership, or to the couple jointly. The gifts can be outright, or in trust (provided that only the couple, their issue and certain other close family members can benefit).
The gift must take place on or before the ceremony and must be conditional on the ceremony taking place. The exemption is not available if the ceremony does not take place.
For more information, see IHT manual: Gifts made in consideration of marriage or registration of civil partnership .

section2.title: Annual exemption
section2.para: Lifetime gifts (which do not fall into any other exemption) are exempt up to £3,000 a year. If the annual exemption is (wholly or partly) unused for a particular tax year, the unused portion may be carried forward for one tax year only. ( Section 19 , IHTA 1984.)
For more information, seeIHT manual: Annual exemption.

section1.title: Potentially exempt transfers
section1.para: A potentially exempt transfer (PET) can be made by an individual. If there are no other exemptions available, the PET might eventually fall out of charge. PETs are:

listitem.para: Outright gifts to individuals.

Gifts to
disabled person's interests
.

When an
immediate post-death interest
comes to an end and the continuing trust qualifies as a
trust for bereaved minors
.

section2.title: Amount of tax charged depends on how long the donor survives
section2.para: PETs are called "potentially" exempt, because if the donor survives for seven years from the date of the gift, the gift becomes fully exempt.

If the donor fails to survive for seven years, the gift becomes chargeable and will use up all or part of the donor's nil rate band. However, the longer the donor survives after making the gift (subject to surviving at least three years), the lower the IHT. This relief is called "taper relief" and will be calculated as follows:

para.emphasis: Period between the date of gift and the death of the donor
Rate of taper relief (applied to the amount of IHT)

section2.para: (Section 7(4) , IHTA 1984.)
The taper relief is applied to the IHT due, not the value of the gift. As result, the full value of the gift (calculated as the "loss to the donor") uses up all or part of the nil rate band.

For example, Zeb makes a gift of £400,000 to his son Charlie on 1 April 1998. He made no other gifts during his lifetime. Zeb dies on 5 March 2002. Because Zeb has failed to survive for at least seven years from the date of the gift (and as the gift exceeds Zeb's nil rate band), IHT will be payable on the gift, calculated as follows:

Value of the gift (strictly, the loss to Zeb's estate): £400,000. Less two annual exemptions (see Annual exemption ): £6,000. Less the nil rate band on 5 March 2002 (see The nil rate band ): £242,000. Chargeable value of the gift: £152,000.
IHT @ 40%: £60,800. Less taper relief at 20%: £12,160. IHT due on the gift: £48,640.
For more information, see IHT manual: Lifetime transfers: what is a potentially exempt transfer?

section1.title: 10% reduction in rate of inheritance tax for gifts to charity
section1.para: The Finance Act Bill 2012 (F A B 2012) introduce d s a lower death rate of IHT for testators who leave 10% or more of their net estates to charity (clause 207 and Schedule 32, FB 2012) . The lower rate of IHT is will be 36%, instead of 40%. The lower rate applies will apply in relation to the estates of testators who die on or after 6 April 2012 (paragraph 10, Schedule 32, FB 2012) . This will be before FB 2012 receives Royal Assent (probably in July 2012). For more information on the 10% reduction in IHT, seePractice note, Inheritance tax: leaving 10% of an estate to charity.

section1.title: Relief from inheritance tax
section1.para: If the gift is of a certain type of asset, relief may apply to reduce the amount of IHT payable, sometimes to nil.
The following reliefs apply automatically:

listitem.para: Business property relief.
Agricultural property relief.

section1.para: Claims for the following reliefs must be specifically made within two years of the death (or lifetime gift):

listitem.para: Woodlands relief.
National heritage property - conditional exemption.

section1.para: The reliefs are available both for lifetime gifts and on death, except for woodlands relief, which is only available ondeath.

section2.title: Business property relief (BPR)
section2.para: Where the conditions are met:

listitem.para: 100% relief is available for:
unquoted share-holdings;
interests in a business (whether owned as a sole trade or in partnership).
50% relief is available for:
shares in a quoted company (where the donor had control of the company);
assets, such as land and buildings, used by the donor's partnership or company.

section2.para: (Chapter I , Part V, IHTA 1984.)

Generally, the donor must have owned the shares or the business for at least two years prior to the gift or death. Further, certain types of activities and investments are excluded from relief. For example, relief is not available if the business or company's activities consist mainly in dealing in securities, stocks or shares, land or buildings, or making or holding investments.
For HMRC's guidance on business property relief, seeIHT manual: Business relief and businesses (from paragraph IHTM25000).

section2.title: Agricultural property relief (APR)
section2.para: Where the conditions are met, agricultural property may benefit from relief at 100% or 50% (depending on who farms the land and how long the land has been owned). Relief is given on the agricultural value of the land. (Chapter II , Part V, IHTA 1984.)
Business property relief may also be available (after agricultural property relief has been given), for example, where a farmer owns the land and farms it as a business.

For further information, see Practice note, Inheritance tax agricultural property relief: overview
andIHT manual: Agricultural relief (from paragraph IHTM24000).

section2.title: National heritage property - conditional exemption
section2.para: Where property and assets are important to the UK's national heritage, IHT can be deferred, provided that:

listitem.para: A claim is made within two years of the gift or death.
The recipient of the asset gives an undertaking to allow public access and to preserve it.

section2.para: (Chapter II , Part II, IHTA 1984.)
The relief is available for both lifetime gifts and on death, although if a lifetime gift, the property must have been:

listitem.para: Owned by the donor (or his spouse or civil partner) throughout the six-year period before the gift; or
Inherited (at any time, even within the six-year period before the gift) and a conditional exemption applied when inherited.

section2.para: An IHT charge arises if the undertakings are broken or the recipient disposes of the property. If the recipient keeps to the undertakings, heritage property can pass down from generation to generation without any charge to IHT.
For more information, seePractice note, Inheritance tax: conditional exemption for heritage property.

For HMRC guidance, seeIHT manual: Heritage property (from paragraph IHTM04111), IHT manual: Exemptions - conditional exemption (paragraph IHTM11260)
and HMRC: Capital Taxation and the National Heritage (September 2011)
(Chapters 4 - 7).

section2.title: Woodlands relief (on death)
section2.para: Woodland may qualify for:

listitem.para: Agricultural property relief, if it is ancillary to farmland.
Business property relief, if it is commercial woodland.

section2.para: If neither of these reliefs apply, woodlands relief might be available.

Woodlands relief is only available on death and operates as an IHT deferral. Where the conditions are met, an election can be made to exclude the value of the timber (but not the land) from the value of the estate for IHT. When the timber is sold (or given away), the sale proceeds (or the market value at the date of the gift) is charged to IHT. The election must be made within two years of death.
Woodlands relief is available where:

listitem.para: The deceased owned an interest in the land on which the timber has been growing (either outright or through a qualifying interest in possession) for at least five years; or
The deceased received the interest in the land by gift or inheritance at any time (including within the five years before death).

section2.para: (Chapter III , Part V, IHTA 1984.)

Care needs to be taken before making an election for woodlands relief, because IHT will be payable on the future sale proceeds (or the market value of the timber, if given away). If the timber is not worth very much on death (for example, because the trees are still very young) it would be better not to make the election and to pay the IHT instead.
For HMRC guidance, seeIHT manual: Woodlands (from paragraph IHTM04371).

section3.title: EU law
section3.para:
Following the European Court of Justice (ECJ) case Theodor Jäger v Finanzamt Kusel-Landstuhl (Case C-256/06, European Court reports 2008)
and the European Commission's formal request to the UK to change its legislation in relation to APR and woodlands relief (seeLegal update, European Commission asks UK to amend inheritance tax legislation), the Finance Act 2009 extended the scope of APR and woodlands relief to property within the European Economic Area. SeePrivate client tax legislation tracker 2008-09: Agricultural property relief and woodlands.

section2.title: Gifts with reservation of benefit
section2.para:
In order for a lifetime gift to be fully effective for IHT purposes, the donor must give the property away without any strings attached. If the donor retains a significant benefit or enjoyment in the property given away, it will remain part of his or her estate for the purposes of calculating IHT. These gifts are called
gifts with reservation of benefit
(GROBs).
For example, Judy gives her home to her three adult children who live elsewhere. She transfers the legal title into their joint names.

listitem.para: If Judy continues to live at the property rent-free, this is a GROB and the property remains in her estate for IHT purposes.

If Judy releases her reservation (for example, by moving out or by paying her children full market rent), this will be a deemed PET. Provided Judy survives for seven complete years after releasing the reservation of benefit, the deemed PET will be exempt from IHT.

section2.para:
The rule is that the property must be enjoyed to the "virtual exclusion" of the donor. As a result, there is some scope for a very minor reservation of benefit. Examples are set out in IHT manual: The reservation: exclusion of the donor (paragraph IHTM14333)
and include the following scenarios:

listitem.para: The donor pays social visits or stays temporarily at a house given away.
The donor is given the occasional lift in a car given away.

section2.para: These anti-avoidance provisions are found in section 102 of theFinance Act 1986.

In addition, there is no GROB where the gift is exempt from IHT, for example gifts to a spouse or civil partner (see Exemptions available for both lifetime gifts and on death andExemptions available for lifetime gifts only).

section2.title: Pre-owned assets
section2.para:
The GROB provisions were intended to prevent artificial avoidance of IHT by exploiting loopholes in the legislation. They have not been totally successful, as many schemes (usually involving houses or chattels) were created to get round the provisions (one example is the
home loan scheme
). To combat this, the
pre-owned assets charge
(POAC) was introduced with effect from 6 April 2005.

Broadly, POAC applies where an individual gives away property (for example land and buildings, chattels or money and investments) and subsequently benefits from that property (or property derived from it). If caught, an annual income tax charge is imposed on the donor in relation to the benefit he receives from the property, unless he elects for the gift to be taxed as a GROB. The election must be made by the 31 January following the tax year in which the individual first becomes liable to POAC. ( Section 84 and Schedule 15 , Finance Act 2004 andChapter 8 , Part 5, Income Tax (Trading and Other Income) Act 2005.) For HMRC's guidance on this matter, including late elections, see HMRC: IHT manual: Pre-owned assets: Election into inheritance tax
see . HMRC: Income tax and pre-owned assets: detailed guidance: Section 3 - The election into Inheritance Tax
.
There are a number of exclusions and exemptions; however the broad principles are as follows:

listitem.para: Property which is subject to IHT in the hands of the donor (for example, property in which he has reserved a benefit) should not be subject to POAC.

Property which is not subject to IHT because it qualifies for favoured IHT treatment (for example, because it benefits from an exemption or relief, such as the spouse exemption), should not be subject to POAC.
Any other property which has been given away, and from which the donor derives a benefit, should be caught by POAC.

section2.para: For full details of HMRC's guidance on POAC, seeHMRC: Income tax and pre-owned assets: detailed guidance.
